articles.headline: Apple Stores Chief to Take the Helm at J.C. Penney
articles.snippet: J.C. Penney hopes that Ron Johnson, a man who rethought how to sell computers, can also rethink how to sell clothes, cosmetics and accessories.
articles.abstract: J.C. Penney hopes that Ron Johnson, a man who rethought how to sell computers, can also rethink how to sell clothes, cosmetics and accessories.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. C. Penney has poached the head of Apple’s retail stores to head the department store chain, betting that a deity of the digerati can revive its sales in the same way he found success in brick-and-mortar stores for Apple.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: As India’s Growth Slows, Leaders Face Political Headwinds
articles.snippet: Government decision-making has been paralyzed by corruption scandals just as economists say a strong hand is needed to curb rising inflation and slowing growth.
articles.abstract: Government decision-making has been paralyzed by corruption scandals just as economists say a strong hand is needed to curb rising inflation and slowing growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s central government, convulsed by a series of corruption scandals, is under increasing pressure to deal with the potentially conflicting challenges of rising inflation and slowing growth.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Lydia Polgreen

articles.headline: Candidates Show G.O.P. Less United on Goals of War
articles.snippet: Some presidential candidates are shifting from the hawkish consensus on national security that has dominated Republican foreign policy for a decade.
articles.abstract: Some presidential candidates are shifting from the hawkish consensus on national security that has dominated Republican foreign policy for a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: DERRY, N.H. — The hawkish consensus on national security that has dominated Republican foreign policy for the last decade is giving way to a more nuanced view, with some presidential candidates expressing a desire to withdraw from Afghanistan as quickly as possible and suggesting that the United States has overreached in Libya.

articles.headline: Banks Turn to Schumer on Patents
articles.snippet: Senator Charles E. Schumer inserted into a bill a provision that appears aimed at helping banks address a costly problem with a patented system for processing digital copies of checks.
articles.abstract: Senator Charles E. Schumer inserted into a bill a provision that appears aimed at helping banks address a costly problem with a patented system for processing digital copies of checks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years and much to their frustration, big banks have paid hundreds of millions of dollars to a tiny Texas company to use a patented system for processing digital copies of checks, making Claudio Ballard, the inventor of the system, a wealthy man and the bank industry’s biggest patent foe.

articles.headline: Cutting the Deficit, Adding Jobs
articles.snippet: Both parties have reason to compromise on the debt talks under way as the economy shows signs of stumbling.
articles.abstract: Both parties have reason to compromise on the debt talks under way as the economy shows signs of stumbling.

articles.headline: A Slowdown for Small Businesses
articles.snippet: A trade group’s report says more small companies plan to shrink their work forces than expand them in the coming months.
articles.abstract: A trade group’s report says more small companies plan to shrink their work forces than expand them in the coming months.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the latest sign that the economic recovery may have lost whatever modest oomph it had, more small businesses say that they are planning to shrink their payrolls than say they want to expand them.

articles.headline: Shuttle’s End Leaves NASA a Pension Bill
articles.snippet: NASA is planning to spend about half a billion dollars next year to replenish the pension fund of United Space Alliance, which supplies workers to the space shuttle program.
articles.abstract: NASA is planning to spend about half a billion dollars next year to replenish the pension fund of United Space Alliance, which supplies workers to the space shuttle program.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s space agency plans to spend about half a billion dollars next year to replenish the pension fund of the contractor that has supplied thousands of workers to the space shuttle program.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Workers Try the Nonunion Route
articles.snippet: After failed attempts to unionize Wal-Mart stores, the nation’s main union for retail workers decided to help create a nonunion group that has signed up thousands of members.
articles.abstract: After failed attempts to unionize Wal-Mart stores, the nation’s main union for retail workers decided to help create a nonunion group that has signed up thousands of members.
articles.lead_paragraph: After numerous failed attempts to unionize Wal-Mart stores, the nation’s main union for retail workers has decided to try a different approach: it has helped create a new, nonunion group of Wal-Mart employees that intends to press for better pay, benefits and most of all, more respect at work.

articles.headline: Pakistan Arrests C.I.A. Informants in Bin Laden Raid
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s detention of five C.I.A. informants, including a Pakistani Army major, is the latest evidence of the fractured relationship between the United States and Pakistan.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s detention of five C.I.A. informants, including a Pakistani Army major, is the latest evidence of the fractured relationship between the United States and Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pakistan’s top military spy agency has arrested some of the Pakistani informants who fed information to the Central Intelligence Agency in the months leading up to the raid that led to the death of Osama bin Laden, according to American officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Lead Poisoning in China: The Hidden Scourge
articles.snippet: Over the past two and a half years, thousands of workers, villagers and children have been found to be suffering from toxic levels of lead exposure, mostly caused by pollution from battery factories.
articles.abstract: Over the past two and a half years, thousands of workers, villagers and children have been found to be suffering from toxic levels of lead exposure, mostly caused by pollution from battery factories.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENGXI VILLAGE, China — On a chilly evening early last month, a mob of more than 200 people gathered in this tiny eastern China village at the entrance to the Zhejiang Haijiu Battery Factory, a maker of lead-acid batteries for motorcycles and electric bikes. They shouldered through an outer brick wall, swept into the factory office and, in an outpouring of pure fury, smashed the cabinets, desks and computers inside.

articles.headline: Markets Falter as Worry Rises in Greek Crisis
articles.snippet: Anxious investors feared the situation could spin out of control, igniting crises in other heavily indebted euro zone countries.
articles.abstract: Anxious investors feared the situation could spin out of control, igniting crises in other heavily indebted euro zone countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greece’s financial and political crisis, compounded by new fears about the pace of the United States economic recovery, sent financial markets reeling on Wednesday.
